conclusion: Initial analysis of the optical problem involving refraction and diffraction.
Hemispherical glass brick with flat surface AB facing upward and curved surface downward.
Two monochromatic light beams a and b with different frequencies enter perpendicularly at points equidistant from C.
After refraction, beams intersect at point P inside the glass.
Need to determine if beam b is more likely to exhibit diffraction than beam a.
Both beams enter perpendicular to the flat surface AB, so they don't change direction at this interface.
Inside the glass, the beams travel straight until they meet at point P.
The refraction of light in a medium depends on the refractive index, which varies with the frequency of light.
Frequency and wavelength of light are related by c = fλ, where c is the speed of light.
Frequency of light doesn't change when it travels from one medium to another.
If beam b has a different frequency than beam a, one must have higher frequency than the other.
Diffraction is the bending of waves around obstacles and the spreading out of waves past small openings.
Degree of diffraction depends on the wavelength of the wave and the size of the obstacle or opening.
Diffraction is more pronounced when wavelength is comparable to or larger than the obstacle size.
Beam b must have a longer wavelength than beam a for diffraction to be more likely.
Since f = c/λ, beam b must have a lower frequency than beam a for longer wavelength.
Lower frequency light has longer wavelength and therefore diffracts more.
If beam b has lower frequency than a, then the statement about diffraction is correct.
Need to know which beam has the higher frequency to answer the question.
Beam that bends more inside the glass must have a higher refractive index.
Refractive index is inversely related to the wavelength - higher frequencies experience higher refractive indices.
Since both beams converge at point P, one must bend more than the other.
